text: saudi arabia australia and japan are
among a number of countries who've
lobbied for changes to a crucial report
which underlines the need to move away
from using fossil fuels the lobbying was
revealed in a leak of documents seen by
the bbc saudi arabia is one of the
world's largest oil producers australia
is a major coal exporter and the leak
comes as world leaders prepare to gather
in glasgow for the global climate talks
in 10 days time our climate editor
justin rolat has more details
the clock is ticking on tackling climate
change the science says unless we start
making dramatic cuts to emissions now we
risk very serious consequences
world leaders will be meeting here in
glasgow for a crucial climate conference
in just 10 days
yet leaked documents seen by the bbc
show some countries are pressuring the
un to change its message on the options
for tackling the challenge
saudi arabia australia and japan are
arguing the world doesn't need to reduce
fossil fuel use as quickly as the un
suggests the un says the focus for the
energy sector should be actively phasing
out fossil fuels delete this says saudi
arabia
one aim of the glasgow conference is to
agree an end to the use of coal but
india warns it expects it to remain the
mainstay of energy production for
decades meanwhile brazil and argentina
ask that the evidence that eating less
meat can help cut greenhouse gas
emissions be watered down
the leak consists of thousands of
comments by governments and others to
the scientists responsible for a key un

which passed them on to the bbc i think
the comments of these countries
demonstrates the depth to which they
will go to try and halt progress in

these um science reports and this is
just one part of three are pretty much

scientists who've helped compile these
reports say the un science is objective
there is absolutely no pressure on
scientists to accept the comments so if
the comments are lobbying if they're not

be integrated in the ipcc report
the world has experienced some of the
most extreme weather ever recorded in
recent years they've been terrible

reasons it means says a veteran of many

about
understanding that even though the
challenge is immense there really isn't
an alternative to dealing with it
because within my lifetime even and

glasgow wants to show its best face to

everybody's voice has to be there that's
